meeting_annotations.speaker: Katharine White

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nick Galati
meeting_annotations.transcript: My name is Nick Delati. I'm an assistant professor at Western Washington University. And I'm in the biology department there and my my major research focus is on the cell biology of cilia and how they signal and how they move. So cilia are these whip-like structures that either serve as antenna or they serve as generators of hydrodynamic force to move fluid. And some cilia do both. So some cilia are sensing while they're actually beating through the aqueous environment. And so what I'm interested in understanding is how do these things get built and once they're built, how do they actually transduce signals? Um they they've got some some quirks to them that are not intuitive uh such as that the entire Sonic Hedgehog signaling pathway in mammals operates through cilia by recruiting transcription factors to the tip of cilia and that's required and and for reasons that we don't quite know. So it's really important though to understand how things move within these structures and it's tough because they're 200 nanometers in diameter and about five microns long. So they're they're challenging to image and they're also dynamic. So they can be moving it up to 20 hertz. So they're they're very challenging structure to image. Um and I I'm excited to be here because I feel like, you know, approaching it with my bread and butter fluorescence microscopy, um which is now turning into a little bit of also flint microscopy, it's going to require something more than that. So I'm excited to see if if somebody has any ideas. And the next person that I see is Meleka.

And particularly related to this topic, uh we've been interested in um genome folding, uh nuclear organization, in particular the interaction of uh transcription factors um with uh DNA with the genome and how the underlying folding of the DNA impacts those interactions and how the interactions themselves can change the underlying folding of the DNA. So we do a lot of single molecule tracking um of um transcription factors to try to understand how they interact with the underlying um uh uh chromatin and and and and genome. And we often make inferences from, you know, very short trajectories. These are very short-lived um trajectories because they're limited by the um photo bleaching of the fluorophores. Um and so I'm interested in, you know, um brainstorming about ideas um about how uh to make those inferences more direct, um you know, uh whether something is really binding to DNA or not binding to DNA is I think a measurement that we make that is kind of indirect.
